channel.title: KenSmith tweets
channel.description: A feed of recent tweets from KenSmith.

item.description: "This is a blog, therefore I am free to tell you, dear reader, about these events." "This is a blog, therefore I am obligated to tell you, dear reader, about these events." Both seem right to me. The tools free me, the genre compels me. Maybe that's it.

Putting a "like" on a tweet is a far milder act than retweeting. A "like" is roughly an approving nod to the tweet's writer from across the way. Probably no one else will notice. With a RT we stand before our friends and repeat the writer's words. [Still, it's just a tweet.]
Judging by her social media streams, IN-2nd’s @RepWalorski / @JackieWalorski has nothing specific, nothing useful to say about guns and gun violence in the U. S.

We often hear: “Gunman appears to have acted alone.” But that’s imprecise thinking. Culture cultivates and glamorizes male violence, legislators make guns easy to buy and mental health care hard to find, citizens fail to learn and practice effective activism, eg.
If stamp collectors carried out most of the mass shootings, we’d try to figure out what that means. Angry white men carry out most of the mass shootings. https://t.co/nun1N8YRcu

After gun violence on the innocent, decent people’s thoughts are reflective, spiritual people’s prayers beseech. But you, @RepWalorski, @SenatorBraun, @SenToddYoung, are also legislators who no matter the death toll, no matter the screams, will not legislate. Shame on you.
After gun violence on the innocent,
decent people’s thoughts are reflective, spiritual people’s prayers beseech,
but active citizens don’t stop there.
“It is impossible to prefigure the salvation of the world in the same language by which the world has been dismembered and defaced.” —Wendell Berry https://t.co/xWTUQoUC1M

@EllynStecker John McPhee wrote three books about the geology of North America starting with the rock outcroppings of Manhattan, especially as seen in Central Park. This outcropping is at about 602 W. 114th Street, near a good bookstore, where ordinarily you’d see a residence.
My advice for today: 1. Live near a river. 2. Go take a walk. https://t.co/Z5LSeLQoBN
Sometimes the builders win, sometimes the boulders win. 114th Street just west of Broadway, NYC. https://t.co/fr4169Ff28
According to the calendar in my iPhone, it's spring in the upper Midwest. https://t.co/tV6dI0pRu0

“Thought must work constantly to rescue the historical from the mythic, the specific from the general, the concrete from the banal, especially when we reflect upon war.” —Roy Scranton https://t.co/FWZsXkU0yG
“What distinguishes American exceptionalism is precisely that belief that we are engaged in a complicated, tragic struggle to advance human ideals in a corrupt and fallen world. Even if war is hell, that is, we still see ourselves on the side of the angels.” —Roy Scranton
Robert J. Vlasic linked the brand name of his pickles to humor. https://t.co/RQSBwKTWf0

@katroseellison Well, if you're not joking... Everybody interprets. People interested in hermeneutics ask, How does interpretation work? or What are the pitfalls when we interpret? or How can we interpret better? or How can we best interpret a certain kind of book?
Refugee Blues by W. H. Auden https://t.co/dvHwrJs1yc

“The Washington press corps, which treats politics as something between a baseball game and a Broadway show, was woefully unprepared.” Can’t see what you need to see through that lens. https://t.co/JaP7t3iz3V

Sometimes the real estate developers win, sometimes the boulders win. (A few steps from Broadway on 114th, on the west side.) https://t.co/cysT3gQRz9
https://t.co/UHNtZhpikI

NYC, what is it about you? https://t.co/uWXgVaGYKZ
Unexpected pool of sunlight. https://t.co/qjNy1T8i5c
Patti Smith, charmed by all the good energy in the air, receiving an honorary doctorate at Columbia’s graduation on Wednesday. https://t.co/XElKhqS4HU
Newly minted doctors of some kind or another. https://t.co/ZTwI7j3bkp
Halo advertisement on top of a taxi outside St. Pat’s. https://t.co/OoKikpjCKP
Halfway through Pennsylvania. https://t.co/FRe53NgwMv
Pennsylvania taco stand so far from the city that it had its own ATM. https://t.co/q0NRa6RmrF
If both great speeches and propaganda simplify, repeat, sloganize and fuel emotion, where does that leave citizens of an imperiled democracy? @JeffreyNussbaum @TheCityClub

On Tuesday, in a shady alcove in a great city park, someone who was the spitting image of @RealChalamet tuned his acting chops by offering free performances of Shakespeare monologues for anyone interested who came by. Long, intricate, intimate progressions of thought and emotion. https://t.co/bpiKshn84O
We chatted briefly about the line before “Tomorrow, and tomorrow, and tomorrow . . . “ when Macbeth realizes he has no time to grieve his wife’s death: “She should have died hereafter; there would have been time for such a word.”
Then the actor gave the context for the prison speech from Richard II, and then went into character for that lengthy and meditative speech.
I have been studying how I may compare This prison where I live unto the world: . . .
https://t.co/PDkqIOmCEC
